contentList.content: <LSTag Type="Image" Info="SoftWarning"/> Use items from this chest to learn the mechanics of crafting items, taking them to use for a run is not recommended!

Woven from threads of ethereal silk, this robe carries echoes of the former greatness of the monk to whom it once belonged. Legends say the monk was a master of hand-to-hand combat, able to move with lightning speed, even on the brink of death.
You gain +[2] to your Movement Speed when you have [1]% or less HP.

A sense of tranquility and peaceful thoughts envelops anyone who touches this rough yet pleasant fabric. The robes don't restrict movement in battle, but the fabric seems to have a calming effect on the skin, relaxing muscles and soul alike after a long fight.
After each combat, you bestow upon yourself with Strong Serenity for [1] turns.

You regain [1] at the start of each turn. Dispels when you enter combat.

Healing power is equal to your Wisdom Modifier.

The wearer of these robes may notice that they have few pockets and are sewn in a very strange manner, as if under the influence of some religion. An ancient sage, whose magical power was absorbed by this artifact, mostly traveled through temples, where he preached his false religion. Perhaps you will succeed in preaching this strange religion better?

This tunic was stolen from the tomb of Zinghi, a powerful wizard from ancient times. In retaliation, Zinghi's spirit cursed the tunic, condemning whoever possessed it to eternal suffering. Now the tunic passes from hand to hand, granting its wearer the gift of insight, but simultaneously dooming them to persecution and misfortune. Can its new master overcome this curse?
Scoring a Critical Hit, receive Zinghi's Insight for [1] turns.
Your Wisdom, Intelligence and Charisma is increased by [1].

Woven from moonlight and infused with the tears of fallen heroes, these robes bestow upon their wearer the grace of a young master whose dance with blades was cut short too soon. Betrayal by a trusted friend ended the young master's life, but the strength of his talent lives on within the artifact.
When dodging an attack, receive <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="ARMOURC5">Swift Movements</LSTag> until the start of your next turn.

An eastern Faerun master once said, "There are no obstacles except those we have in our minds." Perhaps he was right, but it would still be nice to have an enchanted tunic that improves the wearer's connection to the Ki, without worrying about obstacles in the mind?
Using an action that requires Ki Point, you regain Ki Point with a [1]% chance.

The Beetle Hollow was a cult that practiced magical rituals involving ancient insects, which some may now consider to be unnatural. The cult's adepts were most skilled in charms of concealment and invisibility: studying insects, they learned many useful lessons on what it means to be truly unseen.
Entering the stealth state, you receive Beetle Hollow Cover.

Stealth +[1]~[2], +[2] to weapon attacks.

Dispels when leaving stealth.

The clothes is well-made, using the finest fabric. Need it be said that over hundreds of years, the embroidered royal crest has hardly worn away? Inside, the fabric barely glimmers with the enchantment applied, signifying the importance of the mission of the one who previously possessed this artifact.

Stealth +[1].
+[3] to Movement Speed while you are not in combat.
+[1] to Movement Speed while you are not in combat.
Robes of the Queen of Monks

This is one of the battle suits used by the ancient queen Xin Wu. By the age of 8, she had achieved great proficiency in martial arts and often joined armies in grueling defensive campaigns, defending the independence of a long-forgotten kingdom. The robes are comfortable to fight in and do not hinder any movement; rather, they complement it, giving grace and agility.

You do not provoke Opportunity Attacks.
AC [1].

The legends of who once owned this suit are already forgotten. Perhaps one of the many bandits and rogues who ravaged Faerun during one of the kingdom wars? However, the suit doesn't look plain and seems to enhance the ability to notice even very minor details.

Mercenaries have always been an integral part of Faerun. Many sought their services, especially when it came to delicate matters such as eliminating rival princes vying for the throne or successful kings hindering the rise of other empires. The first owner of this suit clearly approached their work professionally, even enchanting their garments to more accurately direct their deadly strikes against unsuspecting targets who were part of their job.
+[1]~[2] to Attack Rolls and damage against Surprised creatures.
Robe of the Arena Mage Champion

In ancient times, kings often organized battles in arenas for the amusement of the common folk. The arena saw strong warriors, cunning archers, and skilled mages. One such fighter owned this robe, in which he practiced what was known as "precision magic," allowing him to achieve insane victories over superior opponents.
Casting a spell or a cantrip in combat, you receive <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="ARMOURC12">Swirling Magic</LSTag> until the end of your turn.
+[1] to a spell or a cantrip Attack Rolls.

Weak students were not favored in the mage guild. Thus Gerenthal trained tirelessly, outpacing all his peers in mastering magical tricks. Unfortunately, while others studied magnificent but boring treatises, Gerenthal practiced fun tricks and minor spells. When the time for major exams came, he predictably flunked out of studying. After that, he lived entertaining drunkards in taverns with fancy magical tricks. His robe, however, captured his challenging life.

+[1] to Cantrip Attack Rolls.

Effectiveness increases every [2] levels.

It is said that this robe was one of the main discoveries when adventurers uncovered the legendary tomb of the fearsome wizard Ytsuken. In itself, it doesn't seem particularly special, but the power contained within it amplifies the wearer's magical abilities tens of times. Naturally, renowned mages immediately coveted such luxury, some of whom met untimely deaths in pursuit of the artifact.
Half of your Intelligence Modifier is added to the damage of your Cantrips(rounded up).

All travelers exploring the Underdark should always be prepared. Dark caves teeming with terrifying monsters and bloodthirsty drow elves are the least of the problems in this wondrous place. Especially well-prepared is the one who considers applying protective charms to their attire and can remain calm even in moments of the greatest danger lurking behind every stone.
Whenever you cast levelled transmutation spell, receive Shield of the Weave.

First damage you receive will be reduced by [1].

Scales from doubled Intelligence Modifier.

The greatest minds of the millennium worked on perfecting the Weave robe, which, according to manuscripts, was supposed to recover even the most severe wounds. Unfortunately, the leadership of this project entrusted it to one of the most terrible wizards, and he, of course, failed the project, creating something extremely unremarkable in the end. The robe was given to the men, to one of the ancient kings - who successfully eased his chronic arthritis with it.
When healed by a spell, you receive Excess Magical Matter.

A powerful sorcerer possessed this robe a thousand years ago, and since then, the fabric has not worn at all, indicating the direct influence of powerful spells on the artifact. The robe was passed down from generation to generation but was ultimately wrested from the last owner by sheer force of overwhelming numbers. However, for a non-innate sorcerer, it's just a trinket, a piece of cloth.
By casting <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="TIDES_OF_CHAOS">Tides of Chaos</LSTag>, you receive <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="ARMOURC17">Shield of Unstable Magic</LSTag>.

First damage you receive will be reduced by [1].

Scales from Charisma Modifier .

The companions marveled at the resilience of the sorcerer of their group, which had been sent to a remote island to deal with a clan of bloodthirsty gnolls: after the hardest fights, he would shake off pieces of gnoll meat from his robe and drink a vial of potion as if nothing had happened. Little did one know that it was the robe inherited from his father that gave him such healing power. Years passes and the sorcerer was suddenly unable to recover from one of the fights, as a severed head could not simply be put back in place.
After combat, regain [1] for each level of sorcerer.

Megalis was not the only prophet of the temple of Storm, but one of the most steadfast. He remained alone to defend the temple gates against stormy monsters, naturally seeking to seize the magical altar of storm and thunder, when all his companions fled and hid from helplessness. He survived many wounds, and some even impressed themselves on his robe. It's unknown how this artifact ended up so low on the ground, but it certainly belongs to the sky.
You gain Resistance to[2] and[3] when you have [1]% or less HP.

The first owner didn't have a chance to fully utilize this robe: the enchantment within it was too potent to control, and the wizard, in a burst of uncontrollable magic, incinerated himself with a fireball.
Taking damage in combat, regain a Sorcery Point with a [1]% chance.

Every time someone speaks of Nigorick, his spirit grows stronger and stronger. Over millennia, his spirit became so powerful that he was able to weave a special, dark, magical robe, which he placed into the world in hopes that someone would find it. Then Nigorick could amplify the evil intentions of the wearer and wreak even greater havoc, harshening the world in his likeness.

When a target is affected by your curse(excluding Hex!), it must also succeed a Wisdom Saving Throw or be affected by the Ancient Curse.

Difficulty Class depends on your Spell Save DC.

This cloth armour was crafted and enchanted by elven armouries long ago to protect against mental influence, which was quite rare but you never know what warriors of your guard will face. But how did the elves lose this gear?

There once lived a black sorcerer, so black that leaves and flowers withered beside him as he strolled through his domain in the middle of the Gloomy Forest. He usually lured children and conducted magical experiments with them, but he was caught on the orders of the local king and sent to the front against hordes of northern centaurs. It was in the brutal battles that this robe(sewn from the skin of centaurs) appeared, from which the sorcerer drew strength for his magic.
Killing a foe in combat, receive [1] charge of Dark Saturation.

+[1] to a spell Attack Rolls and Spell Save DC for each charge of dark saturation.

You must succeed a Charisma Saving Throw([2]) each turn to keep this effect.

Dispels at the end of combat.

Crafted 12,000 years ago by the moon elves of the realm of Keltolmir, this robe was considered a legend of elven enchanting mastery. The green fabric is made from reworked scales of a green dragon, and the reinforced leather is stitched with silvery threads of moonlight. Once, this artifact could allow its wearer to fly among the birds and return to life after death, but now it is merely a shadow of its former power.

One of the typical enchanted garments used by battle mages in ancient wars. The enchantment is extremely simple, yet extremely effective, allowing deadly elemental attacks even through magical barriers.
Dealing damage with a spell or a cantrip, receive <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="ARMOURC25">Unlimited Power</LSTag> until the end of your turn.
You ignore all <LSTag Tooltip="Resistant">Resistances</LSTag> and <LSTag Tooltip="Immune">Immunities</LSTag> to[1],[2],[3],[4] and[5].

Made of an extremely dense material, this seemingly unremarkable barbarian tunic doesn't display all of its benefits. Hidden in the pockets are specially selected smooth, glowing multicolored gems left by the former owner, which stop glowing when outside the tunic. The gems are remnants of ancient cave crystals and together create the harmony of healing magic.
When you have [1]% or less HP in combat, you receive Crystal Healing for [2] turns.

At the end of each turn, you regain [1].

Scales from Constitution Modifier multiplied by [2](rounded down).

For the nomadic people, this tunic is a rare find as it carries strengthening charms. The artifact reacts to the wearer's body temperature and mood, allowing easier movements and sometimes even saving them from certain death.
+[1]~[2] to Dexterity Saving Throws in Rage.

In ancient times, some tribes had quite a large number of warriors to protect their fragile borders, but the shamans were the most fearsome among them. Occasionally, they called upon the forces of nature and unleashed a deadly storm upon hordes of enemies, but often they were just serious warriors unafraid of death. Shamans were valued and respected by the entire tribe, second only to the chief. This is what remains of one such shaman, although some leather elements seem quite fresh.

While in Rage, you deal [1] with your weapon, unarmed and throwing attacks.

Effectiveness increases every [2] barbarian levels.
Apply <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="HASTE">Haste</LSTag> to yourself without spending resources.

In moments of despair, Meristos beseeched his god: "Descend upon me with your grace, grant me salvation from my enemies!" And so he was endowed with divine powers by the charm of the elements, and so Meristos immediately destroyed all his enemies, later becoming a great king. All the clothing he wore at that moment was charged with the power of the elements and stored in the royal treasury for several thousand years, until finally, demonic forces destroyed the kingdom, and barbarians looted what remained.
Taking a Critical Hit, you deal [1] in return and can Prone an attacker.

According to legends, Olesh was a kind friend to people and always came to their aid, despite being a forest hermit. But legends often lie, as it was not written in them that Olesh helped his "friends" by taking one soul in return, gaining animal powers that helped him accomplish the missions people set for him.
When throwing a creature in combat, you gain <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="ARMOURC30">Boiling Blood</LSTag> until the end of your next turn.

Forged in the heart of an enchanted glade, this armour hums with the tranquil whispers of nature. A relic of the serene guardians, it was said to have the power to mend flesh and spirit during the quiet lulls of twilight refrains.
By performing <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_SongOfRest">Song of Rest</LSTag>, you will also fully regain your <LSTag Tooltip="HitPoints">HP</LSTag>.

Cloth of pale lavender, interwoven with threads of silver inspiration, these vestments were once the prize of a legendary bard whose melodies could sway the hearts of stone. With each note, chance itself was charmed to bestow his favor anew.
Using Cantrip in combat, you regain a Bardic Inspiration charge with a [1]% chance.

Clad in shadows and whispers of the nether realm, this armour was worn by a warrior who thrived in the aftermath of battle, drawing power from the demise of his enemies. The dark energies seep into the wearer, a double-edged sword promising strength... and the risk of consuming darkness.
Killing a foe, gain [1] charge of Creeping Saturation.

+[1] to Spell Save DC for each charge of this effect.
You take [2] each turn.

If the charges become [3] or more, the saturation dispels and you take [4].

Doesn't dispels over time.

Woven by a reclusive sect of mage-smiths, this armour is said to harness the very essence of vitality. It grants not only protection but also the ability to draw upon an inner reservoir of life, much like the ethereal warden who remains unseen yet ever vigilant.
Using False Life in combat, regain yourself [1]% of your maximum HP.

A distinctive Circle of the Moon sigil, embroidered from exquisite Baldurian colored cotton, adorns the front of this unusual armour. You notice something else: on the inner part, there's also an atelier imprint and address embroidered. It appears this was a special order, undoubtedly crafted by local wizards as well.
While you are in Wild Shape, your Dexterity is increased by [1].

Wrought from the groves where spirits whisper, this armour amplifies the bearer's necrotic touch with the sagacity of the ancients. Those who don it are said to channel the very depth of wisdom, allowing their morbid spells to seep into foes with intensified malice.

Dealing[1] to a creature deals [2].

Scales from your Wisdom Ability Modifier.

Wrought from the heart of the oldest forests, this armour carries the resilience of ancient trees. Druids who don these garments find their connection to the natural cycle amplified, often seeing their powers restored as swiftly as nature reclaims the land.
Spending a charge of Natural Recovery, you with a [1]% chance immediately recover it.

Crafted under the light of a silver moon, these robes are imbued with the raw intensity of the celestial spheres. Adorned with symbols of the heavens, they offer the wearer a glimpse of divine power—blessing and bane entwined in the fabric of the cosmos.
Using Moonbeam, you receive Fury of the Heaven for [1] turns.

Dealing[1] with a spell or a cantrip additionally deals [2].
Each turn you must succeed a Wisdom Saving Throw([3]) or take [4].

Enshrouded in the essence of the silent hunt, this leather is the bane of the unsuspecting. Its dark surface seems to absorb light, a perfect ally to those who strike from the shadows, leaving their prey rooted in place with fear and dark enchantment.

Hitting a foe with a melee or ranged Sneak Attack, you inflict Paralysis if they fail a Constitution Saving Throw.

Difficulty Class depends on your Manoeuvre DC.

Crafted in the shadowed coves of the Thieves' Guild, this armour is stitched with the luck of the gambler and the swiftness of the wind. Each successful strike from the unseen may grant the agile wearer another chance to dance with fate.

Hitting a foe with a melee or ranged Sneak Attack, you regain all Bonus Action Points.

Triggers no more than once per turn.

This leather tunic, reinforced with arcane stitching, was once worn by a guildmaster of the unseen. It grants a surge of vitality as the wearer fades into the invisibility, weaving their life force back with the subtlety of a shadow.
Applying invisibility effects to yourself in combat will regain you [1].

Tailored from the supplest leather, this armour boasts the artisan's skill in creating a protective garment that doesn't sacrifice agility for resilience. The wearer finds their movements are never anticipatory, granting them the chance to act twice as quickly when evading harm.
By <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_Disengage">Disengaging</LSTag>, you restore a <LSTag Type="ActionResource" Tooltip="BonusActionPoint">Bonus Action Point</LSTag>.

This armour, as lithe and lustrous as the silken strands it emulates, was said to be spun by the drow weavers of the underdark. It grants its wearer a spider's deft grace, especially when treading upon their woven masterpieces.
+[1] to Dexterity(up to [2]) and +[3] to AC if you are a drow(or disguised as one) and standing on a web.

The rich magenta of this supple leather is reminiscent of the twilight sky. Favored by human and half-elf diplomats, the garment subtly enhances their natural charisma, making their presence as memorable as their words.
+[1] to Charisma(up to [2]) if you are a human or a half elf (or disguised as them).

Inlaid with intricate patterns that echo the wilds, this leather vestment is more than mere armour. It resonates with the heartbeats of creatures great and small, bestowing upon the wearer an uncanny ability to commune with and soothe the spirits of beasts.

Set with an emerald that pulses with the life force of the wild, this armour was crafted for those who walk in unison with their companions. Each mend by the beastmaster's hand is echoed in their allies, sealing wounds with the resilience of the untamed spirit.
Healing a creature you summoned, regain it [1].

Forged from the silver heart of a fallen star, this armour was crafted by a legendary smith as a bane to giants. Its enchantment confounds the mighty, making the wearer elusive and difficult to grasp, as though they walk between the very threads of size and space.
Monstrosities have Disadvantage on Attack Rolls against you. You are reduced in size - allowing you to squeeze through small gaps and large crowds of creatures.

This leather armour is veined with alchemical silver, invoking the capricious nature of morning mists. In the heat of battle, it reacts to the wearer's pain by shrouding them in a protective fog, although the volatile magic can sometimes obscure even their own vision.
When taking damage in combat, you create a fog cloud around you for [1] turns. However, you must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw([2]) or get blinded for [1] turns.

Crafted from the softest yet sturdiest leather, this armour is designed to move as if part of the wearer's own body. Its subtle reinforcements at critical points allow for swift, unpredictive movements, granting an edge when evading spells or traps.

This elegantly crafted cuirass is infused with the essence of bewilderment. Legends tell of a cunning enchanter who wove spells into the very metal, causing disarray among foes with just the presence of the bearer, clouding minds as easily as one draws breath.

Each turn in combat, all creatures within [1] of you must succeed a Wisdom Saving Throw or become Confused.

Difficulty Class depends on your Spell Save DC.

Whispered in the ancient tomes of Candlekeep are tales of the Zephyr Gloves — elegant and turquoise as the sea, once worn by the elf Elaendor Windwing. Renowned for his swiftness and mastery over the winds, he imbued these gloves with enchantments that could slow his foes, as if the very air opposed their advance. Lost with Elaendor's passing, the gloves resurface in dire times, turning the tide of battle with unassuming grace — a symbol of hope and the wind's power to alter destiny.
A foe that takes damage from you with a melee weapon or unarmed attack must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw or be affected by a Aggressive Gusts of Wind for [1] turns.
This creature uses [1] times more its Movement Points.

These shadowy gloves once belonged to the legendary thief Shagar, famed for vanishing from the most secure vaults. Enchanted to strike with such speed that foes had no time to react, they were instrumental in his daring escapades. Tales whisper that Shagar used these Foxgloves in his final and greatest escape, after which he vanished without a trace, leaving behind only this artifact.
Using Dash in combat, you gain +[1]~[2] to melee weapon Attack Rolls until the end of your turn.

Once worn by the mightiest dragonborn champion of Tymanther, these gauntlets were crafted from the hides of ancient beasts and adorned with studs. Designed for those whose veins run with draconic blood, they allowed the champion to unleash their heritage's power with every strike, infusing their attacks with destructive might. Now, grips await a new hero worthy of continuing the dragon warrior's path.
Weapon attacks deals [1] if you are dragonborn or disguised as one.

Legend has it that this ancient artifact once belonged to a tribe of wandering monks who unraveled the secrets of the winds ruling over the plains. Whisper to the gloves, and they'll whip up a breeze faster than you can say "tailwind." With every move, the warrior wearing them becomes less vulnerable, as if the air itself weaves an impenetrable armor around him. After the monks mysteriously vanished, the gloves were lost — only to resurface in the hands of adventurers and antique dealers ever since.
Upon hitting with your melee weapon or unarmed attack, you gain +[1] to AC until the start of your next turn.

These bracers once graced the wrists of Iv'rina, a drow whose knack for traps made even the boldest denizens of the Underdark a bit uneasy. She was said to weave the very webs of the world, luring unsuspecting souls into snares crafted with unnerving precision. Once ensnared in her silken nets, her foes were utterly helpless — one swift strike was all it took. Legend has it that Iv'rina had the cheek to challenge Lolth herself, aiming to usurp the title of Mistress of Spiders. How that little adventure concluded is anyone's guess, but from that day forward, her bracers, imbued with ancient magic — vanished. They've a habit of turning up in the most unlikely places, a quiet reminder that overreaching ambitions can leave you more tangled than triumphant.
+[1]~[2] to Attack Rolls if the target is standing on a web surface.

These hefty plate gauntlets once encased the hands of Astorn, the final guardian of Hardur Fortress. When the enemy breached the walls and all hope seemed lost, Astorn stubbornly refused to retreat. Instead, he busied himself healing fallen comrades, all the while inviting the enemy's best efforts to dislodge him. Each act of healing seemed to fortify him further, as if the fortress itself lent him its unyielding resilience. In the fortress's last stand, Astorn fell — but not before making quite the impression. His gauntlets, now imbued with the magic of his indomitable will, have a habit of turning up in the most unexpected hands. They serve as a steadfast reminder that sometimes the best offense is a good — well, refusal to go anywhere, really.
When you heal with a spell, you gain +[1] AC until the start of your next turn.

These gloves once belonged to Taeris, a mighty battle-mage, whose strength and resolve became the stuff of legend. Far from being mere armor, they served as conduits for magic, drawing strength from every enemy he vanquished. With each victory, Taeris grew more powerful, yet more distant, as though the void of the cosmos itself beckoned him. In his obsession with power, he failed to see the strike that would bring his end. The gloves, like the rest of his gear, were scattered, taken by goblins, and sold for a pittance in a distant town — their true power forgotten by those unworthy of it.
When you kill a foe in combat with a levelled spell, regain an Action Point.

These bracers once belonged to Laren Sharpsight, an archer of the Sylvan elves, devoted to Silvanus. During the war against the empire of Calimshan, the elves struck from the shadows of their ancestral forests, raining arrows upon their foes from afar. Laren, among their most skilled bowmen, was famed for never missing his target. The magic within these bracers guided his arrows with perfect precision. After Laren's death in a brutal ambush, the bracers fell into the hands of the Calimshan soldiers and were soon sold off, their true history forgotten — reduced to nothing more than a curious trinket among the clutter of the market.

These gloves once graced the hands of an infamous assassin from Amn, a figure whose victims always met their end in the comfort of darkness. Infused with the power of forbidden rituals, the gloves could, with a mere snap, plunge weaker souls into blindness, leaving them defenseless before their fate. Yet, this prized relic vanished without a trace, along with its master, after his audacious attempt on the life of the city’s mayor. What became of the assassin remains a mystery, and the gloves, steeped in shadowy magic, have not surfaced since — leaving only whispered legends in their wake.
A foe damaged by you with a melee weapon or unarmed attack must succeed a Dexterity Saving Throw([2]) or go blind for [1] turns.

Forged by Grothan, master of runes and craftsman of Clan Rednagg, these gloves were inscribed with runes of great power, their enchantments unmatched in all the dwarven realms. At the zenith of their craft, Clan Rednagg stood as the foremost among those who wielded runic magic, and the Deathgrips, as they came to be called, were the pinnacle of their arcane endeavors. The gloves drew upon the very spirits of the clan’s ancestors, channeling their might into the hands of those who bore them. Many a warrior, whose name now echoes in legend, owed their feats to these gauntlets, for they bestowed strength beyond mortal measure. In the heat of battle, the last known bearer, a dwarven lord of great renown, fell under the foul curse of a necromancer. With his fall, the Deathgrips vanished into the mists of time, passing into the hands of both the righteous and the wicked, each leaving their mark on history, but none able to unlock their full power as of old.
Dealing damage with a weapon in combat, you gain [1] charge of Rune of Power.
Your weapon deals [1] more damage for each charge of this effect. After accumulating [2] charges, you absorb them and gain Rune of Supremacy.
Your next successful weapon attack will cause a guaranteed Critical Hit.

Hakan Blackflame, once a disciple of the Sun Soul Order, forsook their teachings of light, believing true strength lay in the chaos of fire. Through forbidden rituals, he forged these bindings, channeling power from the very heart of the flame. His rise culminated in the founding of Dragon’s Flame Fortress in eastern Amn, where he waged war against the united forces of Amn and Tethyr. Though many paladins of Lathander fell to his flames, Hakan met his end against an entire army, consumed by fire, leaving only these bindings behind. Long forgotten in a mage’s vault, they were eventually stolen and sold as little more than a scrap of cloth in a bustling marketplace.
When dealing[3] to a creature with an unarmed attack, you regain [1] Ki Point with a [2]% chance.

Crafted by Laerimar of Neverwinter, a master of arcane intricacies, these gauntlets were forged in the royal smithy to his exact specifications. Each pattern etched upon them carried a unique enchantment, forming a combination of spells never before seen, granting untold magical potential. Yet, wary of the instability in his creation, Laerimar hid the gauntlets in a solitary tower atop a mountain, surrounding them with a labyrinth of traps. Years later, he passed away, and the gauntlets, cut off from their creator, began to lose their power. Over 842 years later, a band of adventurers breached the tower, bypassed the traps, and claimed the relic. Finding it of little use, they bartered it for a couple of healing potions at a local shop.
By Concentrating on a spell, you gain +[1] to a Spell Save DC and spell Attack Rolls.

In the hidden forges of Lantan, where artifice and sorcery entwine, these gloves were wrought as part of a secret endeavor to bend the very forces of sound to mortal will. The Lantans, ever the masters of blending arcane with machine, crafted the Vibro-Gloves, yet their work was marred by the gloves’ unruly nature. In time, the project was forsaken, and the gloves were lost to the halls of memory. It was only by the daring of a lone engineer that they were smuggled from the island, sold in the shadowed markets to adventurers unaware of their peril. For within these gauntlets, the essence of sound lies coiled like a tempest — unleashed only by those both wise and wary, lest they be consumed by the chaos they contain.
Dealing[3] in combat with a spell or a cantrip, you gain [1]/[2] charges of an Essences of Vibration.

[1] to AC(regardless of charges).
After accumulating [2] charges of this effect, you absorb them and gain a Sonic Strike.

Does not dispels over time.

Your next successful melee attack will also deal [1].

Effectiveness increases every level.

Forged in the boundless northern wastes, these gloves were long wielded by the mages of the remote Uthgardt tribe. The threads woven into their fabric were crafted from a rare northern metal, the secrets of its forging lost to time. The Uthgardt, having discovered a spool of this strange thread amidst the ruins of an ancient civilization, used it to strengthen their bond with the Weave. The gloves’ devastating power often served the tribe in defending their frozen homeland, and the artifact itself came to be revered as a sacred idol, passed down through generations in a solemn ritual. But in the end, the Uthgardt were laid low by the giants, and the relic, along with their memory, was swallowed by the endless snows, lost forever to the world.

Spells and cantrips of[2] deal [1].

Effectiveness increases from your Intelligence Modifier.

For many a year, these gauntlets were in the possession of Largis Torren, a renowned battle-mage and commander, famed for his daring stratagems and unmatched valor upon the field of war. Among his many feats was the winning of these enchanted gauntlets in a game of chance against a crafty goblin. Yet, in time, they were purloined from his chambers by shadowy thieves, and since that day, they have appeared at various auctions and markets, bringing misfortune to all who sought to wield their might. Each new owner has struggled to harness their power, often meeting a most unfortunate and comical demise. "A gift from my dear student," Gond's high artificer would say of this unassuming hat, "though I'm still uncertain if it was meant as a jest or an insult." The student, after failing every exam spectacularly, left only a note: "Since you taught me nothing, perhaps this will help you teach better." Decades later, the artificer finally admitted the boy might have been cleverer than anyone suspected.

When assassins finally traced Morlith the Tideshaper to Baldur's Gate harbor, they thought the lone water mage would be easy prey. The fluid helm he wore - a casual masterpiece of his water-shaping art - had other ideas. As their spells converged, the harbor itself rose up through the helm's flowing form, turning their magic to mist. "Next time," read Morlith's soggy letter to his would-be killers, "perhaps try attacking a water mage somewhere less wet?" The helm still ripples with amusement when worn near assassins' guilds.
You are Resistant to all damage while standing in water surface.

When the legendary General Sun was asked how he mastered every weapon, he smiled and said: "A great warrior does not fear the ten thousand weapons - he makes them fear him." Found centuries later in the Sword Coast's bustling trade ports, this helm still bears inscription in careful calligraphy: "To my most stubborn student - may you finally learn that mastery comes from wisdom, not just practice." The General's signature below appears to have been added rather hastily, as if dodging a thrown practice sword.
You gain Proficiency with all martial weapons.

When Master Tinker Glimmerwheel unveiled his latest invention at the Grand Mechanists' Fair, onlookers were puzzled. "It slows things down?" they asked. "But why?" The answer came during the fair's notorious Construct Race, where his rivals' supposedly-perfect automata stumbled like drunken dwarves. "Sometimes," he grinned from beneath his helm, "winning isn't about going faster - it's about making everyone else go slower." The Mechanists' Guild banned the helm from future competitions, right after they finished laughing.
All constructs within [1] of you lose half their Movement Speed and Vulnerable to all damage (unless they are immune to it).
All constructs within [1] of you lose half their Movement Speed and Vulnerable to all damage (unless they are immune to it).
This construct is affected by the Decelerator's nullifying field, loses half its Movement Speed and Vulnerable to all damage (unless it immune to it).

Warchief Kraggoth was notorious for laughing at the worst moments - during funeral rites, diplomatic meetings, and especially while being stabbed. His warriors thought him mad until they realized no blow could stop his cackling. "Death," he'd roar between laughs, "is just a particularly long nap!" After thirty arrows, two ballistas, and a falling tree finally ended his rampage, his helm stayed behind, still sharing its former master's morbid sense of humor with anyone brave enough to wear it.
You cannot be Unconscious, Stunned, or Incapacitated while at [1]% HP or more.

At the Gates of the Abyss, Warlock Malekhast made his final stand. Holding a barrier against demon hordes with one spell while unleashing destruction with another, he bought precious time for the reinforcements to arrive. The price was steep - each dual-cast tore at his mind until nothing remained but ash and victory. Only ashes remained of the warlock, but his silver circlet survived, and its pristine surface forever marked by that desperate hour - a reminder when one's divided focus saved the Sword Coast from damnation.
You have <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on spell <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag> while <LSTag Tooltip="Concentration">Concentrating</LSTag> on a spell.

When illithids first emerged from the Far Realm, they found mortal minds easy prey - until they met the Silver Crusade. The holy light that blessed these helms proved anathema to creatures of alien thought. During the Mindflayer Wars, a shaft of divine radiance marked each champion who wore one, making them beacons against the darkness. This helm still draws that ancient light, a warning to those who would twist the minds of mortals.
Aberrations have Disadvantage on Attack Rolls against you. You gain Resistance to[1].

High Inquisitor Aurelius crafted this helm in the sacred forges beneath the Radiant Cathedral, infusing it with essence of captured celestial beings. The distinctive avian design was inspired by the legendary phoenix that visited him in a divine vision, promising victory against the undead hordes threatening the realm. For decades, Aurelius led crusades against the most powerful liches and vampire lords, the helm's divine magic turning their own attacks against them. When he finally fell in the Battle of Twilight's End, neither his body nor the helm were found - until now. Though some of its original power has waned, the celestial spirits bound within still burn with righteous fury, yearning to once again banish darkness from these lands.
Undead that deal damage to you must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw([1]) or become inflicted with Celestial Flashes for [2] turns.
This undead is wreathed in celestial flames, losing [1] Strength and Dexterity.

An exiled prince of the Plane of Fire forged this crown through forbidden pacts with flame elementals, seeking power to reclaim his throne. The elementals, ever-tricksters, granted his wish but cursed the helm with an endless hunger for their essence. The crown's appetite grew until it consumed its maker, leaving behind only a whispered warning: "Feed it flames, or it shall feed on thee." Through centuries it passed between realms, each bearer discovering too late that its thirst could never truly be quenched.
While standing on burning surface, you add an additional damage die to your Critical Hits.

Centuries ago, the infamous toxicologist Malakai faced a circle of paladins in his laboratory beneath the Spine of the World. Cornered, he attempted a desperate ritual to temporarily transform his body into pure venom - but the paladins' combined smite disrupted the spell. The magical backlash shattered his physical form, yet his essence, saturated with decades of alchemical experiments, sought refuge in the nearest vessel - his hood. The paladins, sensing only lingering magic in the seemingly harmless garment, catalogued it as evidence and stored it away.
All creatures within [1] of you have Vulnerability to[2] and[3].

The last famous words of Larecius, the gifted sorcerer and owner of this crown, were: "Trust me, I can feel this next fireball coming!" Now it passes between overconfident spellcasters, each convinced they'll master its chaos. Most entertaining: watching them explain to their companions why the "absolutely guaranteed" spell just turned into an awkward moment of finger-wiggling. At least Larecius's ghost gets a good laugh.
When casting a spell or a cantrip in combat, you have a [1]% chance to regain all your Level [2]~[3] Spell Slots.

A peculiar relic from the infamous Underdark mining rush, when prospectors sought rare minerals in the most hazardous depths. Old Gregory, a particularly stubborn dwarf, refused to abandon his claim despite discovering his tunnel network ran straight through a black dragon's lair. The dragon's acidic breath had melted countless mining operations, but Gregory simply enchanted his trusty hat to resist the corrosion. The dragon, thoroughly impressed by the dwarf's tenacity (or perhaps just amused), eventually allowed him to continue mining - for a share of the profits, of course. The hat still seeps corrosive substances when struck - a rather effective reminder of its unusual origin. Just don't wear it to fancy parties!

You are Immune to Acid effects.
When taking melee damage, you coat all surfaces within [1] in acid.

A treasured relic from the Seekers of the Dawn, crafted during their divine mission to establish Lathander's temple in Myth Drannor. When undead forces threatened their restoration efforts in the 13th century DR, this hat was enchanted to channel the Morninglord's protective radiance. The quilted pattern represents the first rays of dawn breaking through darkness, each stitch infused with Lathander's blessing. While its original bearer fell defending the temple foundations, their sacrifice ensured others would live to see the sunrise. These days, the hat still radiates protective light when darkness threatens - though local necromancers insist it's "unbearably flashy." Dawn comes for everyone eventually!
When you take[1], you and your allies within [2] gain Dawn's Blessing for [3] turns.
Resistance to[1] while near the bearer.

Forged in the twilight days of Netheril, this ominous helm once belonged to Archmagister Kroneth, whose obsession with controlling time led him to create increasingly dangerous artifacts. In his hubris, he believed he could master the very flow of time itself, but his experiments only resulted in this cursed crown - a cautionary tale of magical tampering. The helm creates a localized temporal distortion, making it impossible for anyone nearby to perform swift actions. Those who've worn it speak of feeling as though they're wading through molasses, their reflexes dulled by invisible chains. Kroneth himself met his end wearing it, unable to cast a simple Shield spell in time when his own apprentice finally decided she'd had enough of his temporal meddling.
All creatures within [1] cannot take Bonus Actions in combat.
This creature is unable to perform <LSTag Type="ActionResource" Tooltip="BonusActionPoint">Bonus Actions</LSTag>.

It belonged to Knight-Protector Laeranel, whose dedication to her soldiers transcended even death itself. During the siege of Myth Drannor, she led a desperate defense against overwhelming Dark forces. As her warriors fell around her, their life essence began flowing through her helm, creating a cascade of healing energy that kept the remaining defenders alive. The helm's distinctive aqua glow is said to mirror the waters of Evermeet, representing the eternal flow of life and sacrifice. Most telling is that when goblins discovered her remains centuries later, they found her still standing, her armor pierced by countless arrows, yet surrounded by a circle of comrades.
When taking damage from a foe, you heal all creatures within [1] for [2].
Heals the creature for [1] when hit.

In the gilded halls of Lathandar's temple, this peculiar headpiece crowned the most devoted of the Morninglord's servants. The chains adorning it symbolize the eternal cycle of dawn and dusk, each crystalline bead capturing divine energy. Crafted by a blind oracle who "saw" only through divine radiance, the hat channels raw evocation magic into either searing light that burns the wicked or gentle dawn that rejuvenates the faithful. Most amusing was its first test, when its creator accidentally turned an entire squadron of undead into impromptu light sources for the brightest midnight service in temple history.
Your targeted Evocation spells cast on allies or self also heal for [1].
Your targeted Evocation levelled spells cast on foes deal [1].

From this helm seeps an ever-present ethereal darkness, as if the void itself clings to its surface. Ancient texts speak in hushed tones of the Dark One - a being who ascended beyond mortality, now watching from realms unseen. This helm, they say, was worn during their mortal days, before their transformation. Now it serves as a conduit of their continued influence, protecting chosen bearers through supernatural intervention. When death draws near, the black mist intensifies, turning aside even the most lethal blows, while those foolish enough to strike its bearer while weakened simply... cease to be. Most unsettling is how the helm's shadowy vapors seem to move with purpose, as if the Dark One's gaze perpetually lingers upon their ancient possession.
When receiving a Critical Hit, you gain Dark One's Grace for [1] turn.
Humanoid attackers with [1]% HP or less are instantly destroyed.

This peculiar top hat, with its enigmatic patterns, is said to have emerged from the Maze of Fate itself. The Maze, an endless labyrinth existing between planes where destiny's threads intertwine, occasionally produces artifacts of impossible probability. The hat's patterns shift positions when unobserved, each realignment subtly adjusting the wearer's fortune. Its first owner lost it in a bet - though whether this was truly unfortunate or precisely what fate intended — remains a matter of cosmic debate.

Among the celestial archives of Mount Celestia, tales speak of a legendary Planetar who grew fascinated by mortal potential. Breaking tradition, this angel crafted a helm from aureate light and morning clouds, gifting it to a particularly righteous paladin. The helm channels some fragment of the Celestial Planes' divine energy, allowing its bearer to briefly transcend mortal limitations. Its radiant glow intensifies in battle, as if the Seven Heavens themselves reach down to elevate the worthy.
In combat, you become Resistant to all damage and can fly.
Blessed by divine power, you ascend above mortal constraints, gaining the gift of flight and Resistance to all damage.

Forged from otherworldly fel-tainted steel, this helm belonged to Shadowmarch, the last of the legendary Fiendhunters. The helm's distinctive green glow comes from thousands of trapped demon essences, their power turned against their own kind. Each new demonic kill strengthens its wearer, as if the helm itself feasts upon fiendish energy. Ancient texts speak of how the Fiendhunters developed their craft into an art, but none mastered it quite like Shadowmarch, who discovered that demons' own essence could be their greatest weakness. The helm still hungers for its prey, waiting for a worthy successor to continue the eternal hunt.

When you slay a fiend, restore all HP.
Required roll for Critical Hit against fiends is reduced by [1] (stacks with similar effects).

This opulent hat once belonged to Archmage Valerion, whose mastery of protective magic was legendary even among the Violet Circle. Its intricate silver patterns were woven with threads of pure starlight, each delicate line forming complex wards of unparalleled power. When the dreaded Witch-Queen Mara sought to break his defenses with her thousand curses, she found each spell dissolving harmlessly against his protections. In the end, the most powerful curse-weaver of an age was defeated not by counter-curses or battle magic, but by the simple impossibility of harming one who understood that true power lies not in the ability to curse, but in the art of refusing to be cursed.

Among the rarest treasures of the Astral Sea floats a peculiar phenomenon - living stars of pure consciousness, ancient beings of pure radiance and thought. This circlet was crafted from a willing star's fragment by the legendary artificer Sylandria, who spent a lifetime learning to communicate with these celestial entities. The crystal retains its awareness, its blinding radiance a mere echo of the vast knowledge it contains. Those who wear it find their minds expanded beyond mortal limits, though some say the circlet chooses its bearers as much as they choose it, seeking those whose minds can withstand communion with a star's consciousness.

You gain +[1] to all Skills.
Effectiveness scales with Spellcasting Ability modifier.

In the depths of ancient ruins, where shadows of forgotten times linger still, these weathered boots lay dormant. Upon first touch, your fingers traced patterns that suddenly sprang to life - delicate tendrils of moss weaving stories of ages past across their wooden surface. Your scholarly pursuits led you to dusty tomes speaking of the Verdant Wanderers, an ancient circle of druids who walked the realms in times of legend. These wise folk held that true healing flowed from the embrace of nature itself, and so they bound wild magic into their very footwear. Now, as you don these remarkable boots, you witness a wondrous sight: with each healing surge, tiny flowers burst forth from stone and soil alike, as if the very earth rejoices in your restorative touch.

When you receive healing, you conjure dense flower growth around you for [1] turns. You are not slowed by the flower growth.

Triggers no more than once per turn.

Deep within a dust-laden laboratory cellar, you discovered these peculiar slippers, coated in an odd, viscous substance. Scattered nearby lay charred journal pages, their secrets mostly lost to flame, save for two telling entries: "Day 47: The formula nears completion! The oil has achieved the perfect consistency. Now to address that bothersome slipping issue..." and "Day 48: EUREKA! Ground obsidian should..." The rest trails off into ash and scorch marks. Given the blackened walls and stubborn stains etched into the floor, it appears the author's final experiment went rather... spectacularly. Well, at least now you understand why these slippers have such a peculiar relationship with gravity.
When you use <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_Dash">Dash</LSTag> in combat, your slippers become <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="ARMOURB133">ignited</LSTag> until the end of your turn.
While moving, you occasionally fall prone.
At the end of your turn, the substance coating your slippers <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Armour_B_133_explosion">explodes</LSTag>.

Creates an explosion of unstable substance, covering the ground in fire for [3] turns and dealing [1].

Creatures can succeed a Dexterity Saving Throw to take half damage.

Among the ruins of an ancient temple of the air monks, you discovered these remarkable fur-lined boots. Light as a feather yet surprisingly sturdy. A weathered spellbook found nearby tells of a warrior sect who trained themselves to leap from great heights, descending upon their foes like lightning from the heavens. The ancient magic within these boots seems to retain a fragment of their power still, granting their bearer protection in the most daring of leaps.

You are immune to falling damage. When you Jump, gain [1].

Effectiveness increases every level.

Deep in the windswept steppes, where ancient stones whisper tales of forgotten wisdom, you discovered these cloth wrappings in a monastery untouched by time. Their fabric, though worn by ages past, bears intricate patterns in threads of gold that seem to shift like morning mist when caught by sunlight. As your fingers traced the half-faded symbols, you felt a curious stirring in the air around you. The monastery's archives yielded fragments of an extraordinary tale - of ascetics who had transcended the very bounds of movement, their footsteps so swift and light that witnesses spoke of figures melting into the wind itself. Such was their mastery that they appeared as nothing more than ripples in the air, leaving only swirling dust as testament to their passing.

These otherworldly boots seem to exist outside of time itself. Crimson crystals, inlaid upon their surface, pulse with an unnatural rhythm, while the metal from which they were forged appears fluid, as if uncertain of its own shape in the timestream. In your research through ancient texts, you discovered fragments of astral script, speaking of "one who sought to bind time itself." The remaining passages are hopelessly blurred, as if time itself refuses to reveal their secrets.
Foes within [1] of you lose [2]% of their Movement Speed.
This creature is affected by temporal forces and loses [1]% Movement Speed.

These slippers shimmer with an ethereal blue light reminiscent of lightning dancing across storm-laden skies. As you study their remarkable properties, ancient glyphs of Deep Speech become visible beneath their surface - each crackling with contained power. While experimenting with their curious nature, you discovered their profound reaction to electrical discharge - they seem to awaken, drawing power through their soles like some forgotten astral conductor. In moments of fierce fighting, you feel static charges around your feet merge with the slippers' otherworldly energy, creating a resonance that echoes through the very fabric of space.

When dealing damage with a spell or a cantrip from an electrified surface, you regain an Action Point.

Triggers no more than once per turn.

These blazing boots were discovered in an ancient fire shrine, hovering above an eternally burning altar. At first touch, you felt them resonate with the surrounding flames, as if seeking to bend fire to their will. The longer you study their properties, the more certain you become - these boots do not merely resist fire, but possess the power to transmute its destructive force into healing essence.
When you deal[1] with a spell or cantrip while standing on a burning surface, heal yourself for [2].

At first glance - mere leather boots, worn by time and travel. Yet upon closer inspection, you notice their leather seems to shimmer with an inner divine light, each step leaving traces of luminescence in the air. In rare moments, when light falls just so, you can discern ancient celestial runes woven into the very fabric of the leather. What power bestowed such might upon so humble a vessel? The answer, it seems, has been lost to the ages.
While at full HP, you are immune to being slowed and can fly.
